subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: A couple of questions from a newbie
msgSnippet: ... Sure.  But that s using the QS letter Ah in a standardized way to represent the LOT=PALM lexical set, instead of using it to represent the specific sound
messageBody:
Zyggy2 scripsit:

> You are overlooking the fact that the policeman would probably spell the
> word BAY/LOW/AH/KEY even though he pronounces it ASH. The difference
> is that you hear ASH and he hears AH and likely pronounces all ASH as
> AH in his speaking.

Sure. But that's using the QS letter Ah in a standardized way to
represent the LOT=PALM lexical set, instead of using it to represent
the specific sound [ɑ] (a low back unrounded vowel), contrary to the
original claim that KR intended specific letters to represent specific
*sounds* as opposed to specific phonemes.

--
John Cowan cowan@... http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
C'est la` pourtant que se livre le sens du dire, de ce que, s'y conjuguant
le nyania qui bruit des sexes en compagnie, il supplee a ce qu'entre eux,
de rapport nyait pas. --Jacques Lacan, "L'Etourdit"
